In the age of YouTube, the pivot will be nearly impossible. Every time he tries to gull women, a hoard of bloggers, Facebookers, Tweeters and other users of social media will post the Meghan Kelley clip.

Every time he mentions his stupid idea about a wall, we will keep the Latino voter well poisoned.

We'll be sure to remind everyone with an unusual last name that just this weekend he asked a rally if Kasich couldn't be forced to change the "ridiculous spelling" of his last name.

Every time he tells us how rich he is, it will be pointed out that his fortune would be bigger had he left his inheritance alone and laid on a beach somewhere.

Anyone who thinks we don't have folders of quotes and images, ready to descend on him like the flying monkeys on the Scarecrow in "The Wizard of Oz" -- this must be your first day. Welcome to the internet.  --BG

status_message:
Every four years, the pundit class (who seem to avoid canvassing and phonebanking duties, in the experience of most activist types) tells us how to fix the process. There are a few things about such pieces that make me roll my eyes. 

First off, we need to get more people voting that are *currently* eligible to vote. 

Second, it's like they just pretend that election law can be changed by fiat instead of set by each state...and the primaries are controlled by the PARTIES in each state, and that's just how it is. Until a federal election law is passed, hashed out in the courts and "forced down the throats" of the states (this argument will be made mostly by the states that joined the confederacy and the ones in the libertarian west, where cows outnumber people, a frontier mentality prevails, and the federal government owns wide swaths of land) the election laws and rules will continue to be set by the states and the parties. 

Third...There are a lot of people in this country who consider anything "archaic" a feature and not a bug. Consider that somewhere, this very weekend, there are Civil War battles being reenacted and it hasn't been that long ago that there were people in tri-corn hats and revolutionary war garb parading around and shouting that we should just let sick people die if they couldn't pay for medical care. --BG
link_name: How to Fix Our Broken Primary System in Five Easy Steps

status_message:
"On the Democratic side two consecutive non-incumbent presidential battles will have in theory been decided again not necessarily by the will of the voters, but by the will of a few hundred high-level party insiders."

The Superdelegates aren't nefarious, mobster-like dark entities. They are members of the DEMOCRATIC party and most of them are elected officials, like Congressmen, Governors, Senators, state Attorneys General and Secretaries of State...You know, the Democrats that have already been elected. If you think they're corrupt and subvert the will of the voters, I suggest you read up on the 1972 Democratic primary; then look across the aisle at what is going on with the Republicans and then give thanks that our side does things the way they do. --BG

status_message:
"This fact has become increasingly clear to Americans of all stripes, but especially to 1) downwardly mobile blue-collar whites who used to think that they prospered over minorities by dint of their hard work and industriousness, and now flock to Trump in reaction to their betrayal by Reaganomics; and 2) younger Americans who realize that the deck is entirely stacked against them due to outrageous student loans, low-paying or contract-labor jobs, unaffordable housing costs, etc. Older, more established white collar types don't tend to feel the bite of the broken economy in the same way, and therefore find themselves more attracted to incremental tweaks to the system."

Two things I take issue with here:

First, It is an article of faith among the GOP base that "Reaganomics," like conservatism, can never fail, it can only *be* failed, but don't take my word for it, ask your Republican uncle.

Second, those of us who are "older" and "more established" white collar types busted our humps playing a rigged game for thirty years to get what we have, in spite of the fact that our boats never floated, and we realize incremental tweaks are the only way we get to an outcome we want rather than one we regret for decades. Revolutions have a way of taking on a life of their own and amassing a huge body count along the way.  --BG

I finally got it fixed (it was only Fb and the links on the front page didn't work, I had to go into the settings) a few minutes ago and I will get one or two over here for the nightowls, and get the rest up before the interns start feeding the beast tomorrow.  --BG

status_message:
Fourth wall, schmorth wall.I am doubly invested here, being a mixed-marriage-baby: I have a Catholic father and a Jewish Mother, and I'm a mass-every-Sunday, have-a-Priest-bless-the-house observant Catholic.  That said:

There have been two times since my Confirmation (the bacon cheeseburger, was, ultimately, the only proof I could find that God truly loved me and wanted me to be happy) that I have felt I chose wrong and should have had a Bat Mitzva instead.

The first was when Ratzo became Pope. (I actually identified as Jewish when he was Pope.)

The second was when I read this, as I was changing out of my church clothes.

Peace be with you, one and all, and I mean it from the bottom of my heart.  --BG

status_message: If Donald Trump becomes President, we'll have Ronald Reagan to blame. He started the dumbing-down of America (the man thought ketchup was a vegetable, for God's sake!) he gave the religious-right nutjobs that had been successfully held at bay, a seat at the table. It was during Reagan that America seemed to take a turn toward meanness and incivility that, uncountered, has come to threaten the very things that we used to hold dear as the things that set us apart and gave us the right to claim American exceptionalism in the first place. They want **THEIR** country back? What about those of us who have actually read and understood the Constitution, instead of just waving it in the air and shouting about it? Do we get to say we want our country back yet? --BG

status_message:
Reagan, no question. Besides all the messed up stuff Reagan did (right wing death squads in Central America, the Iran-Contra affair, Decimation of the environment, destruction of the Fairness Doctrine, repeal of alternative energy tax credits, dead Marines in Beirut, over 130 indictment of high ranking administrative personnel...even a part-time Democrat can go on citing examples **ALL DAY LONG.** 

So here are the two points it boils down to...without Reagan we would be 35 years farther down the road to clean, renewable energy -- what a nightmare *that* would be. 

The second point is that without Reagan, there would simply have been no Bush 43.

--BG

status_message:
Did you ever wonder whatever happened to the Acid Rain that was going to kill all that plant life in North America, and by extension, us? It ceased to be an issue because Bush 41 signed the Clean Air Act of 1990 that put a cap-and-trade tax on Sulfur Dioxide, and all of a sudden, the companies that would be bankrupted complied, SO2 stopped turning forests yellow, and we all lived happily ever after.

So riddle me this: Why wouldn't the same thing work for Carbon?  --BG
link_name: Beating Around the Bush: Part I

status_message:
I am reminded that there were two young white male college students arrested in my home state of Missouri because they made threats toward black students at the state's flagship school that were Paris-like in their aspirations. They had the malice and hatred in their hearts to threaten black students for having the audacity to want equal treatment and an environment free of the overt racial bigotry that black students have had to deal with at MU since the first black students were admitted in 1950.  When they finally protested and successfully toppled the university's top leadership, they were vilified by conservatives, and threatened with violence. ("I'm going to STAND MY GROUND and shoot every black person I see.") (emphasis mine.) 

Everywhere you look it seems that hatred and anger are just below the surface. If we don't get our act together soon, I fear there will be a bloodletting like we've never seen, because it will be global in nature. Yes, I hope I'm just being paranoid, too.  --BG

http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/11/11/some-at-u-of-missouri-on-edge-after-social-media-threats-of-violence/75559034/
link_name: 2 suspects arrested in social media threats at Missouri campuses

The history of the early 21st century will be marked by questionable elections.  But if the questions aren't asked now, if we acquiesce to letting those with the money count the votes, we're truly rogered roundly.

Why aren't people in the streets, protesting election anomalies in Kentucky and Kansas? Or did the fact that the Presidency was stolen twice, right from under our noses, and we did nothing, break us and make us accept whoever the Star Chamber chooses at whatever level?  --BG

status_message:
I was in total agreement until this phrase of the post: "For instance, Iran's mullah problem can certainly be traced back to the CIA-backed coup against the democratically elected Mossadegh in the 1950s. But it's also important to note that that was over 50 years ago now..."
Having been to the middle east, that passage reminded me of a proverb I heard while there that perfectly sums up the difference in world views between the west and the rest of the world ..."Anything that you read about that happened in the last 500 years is just journalism." Older cultures have long memories. We as Americans would do well to remember that. Think about it this way: the CIA deposed Mossadegh over 50 years ago, but the Armenian Genocide was 100 years ago, and still a sticking point.  --BG

Uhm...Rand Paul is full of it. I live in a Democratic City that I frequently describe as "the blueberry in the tomato soup" and what we are, is big enough to take care of ourselves. Clean water? Check. Our water is consistently one of the best in the country, and our average bill is about $50 for two months. Our municipal waste costs less than $8 per household for waste disposal and recycling. We have a brand new performing arts center that is akin to the Sydney Opera House. We have universal healthcare for all via the UMKC Medical School and Truman Medical Center. We have a music scene that is rivaled only by Austin, and there are a lot of Austin artists who favor playing here, because our venues are awesome. We have a food scene that is rivaled only by San Francisco, New York and New Orleans. KC is ideally located for organic farmers to sell their products directly to restaurants. We don't just have a world class art museum, we have a Museums District. We have a vibrant arts scene.  We have smooth, paved streets. We have reliable public transit.

We are a Democratic city, and we have nice things, it isn't the hellscape I just heard described. Quite the opposite, actually.
If there is anyone who can run a "big business" like Hewlett-Packard or the U.S government into the ground, it's Carly Fiorina.
Does Jeb! just sound like Charlie Brown's teacher to anyone else?
Kasich makes a bit of sense. What the hell is he doing on this stage with these jokers?

Why are all these candidates talking about welding? 

Robots do that job now.

Neil Cavuto just said it wasn't a game show and all the people in my house busted a gut laughing. Even the 11-year-old who goes to a Catholic school with a 65% Hispanic student population. The parents I spoke with (yes, some in Spanish) were absolutely jubilant that the 5th Circuit slapped down the President's executive order barring millions of undocumented workers from deportation. These new citizens were acutely aware that the ruling will be handed down next summer, and energize the Hispanic vote.

I wish the tea-folk were as savvy about how our system works...No, on second thought, I'm extremely glad they're not.
Here we go...Remember, I've had two brain aneurysms already...I'm taking a great risk to make fun of these fools for you.  --BG
I lost count of the things that were just wrong, but I have seven hashmarks by "outright lies." I was too busy live-blogging this mess to write them down.

Sir Charles of Krauthammer is praising Fox Business for the softballs that were lobbed "this was a real debate, without ad hominem."

Excuse me? Have substantive questions been redefined as "ad hominem attacks" now?

I like the fact that when my doctor writes a prescription, I get the medication that my doctor ordered from the pharmacist.

I like that everyone agrees that red lights mean "stop."

I like that when I put gas in my car, it is the formula that it says it is on the pump.

I like that I live in a state that regulates electricity so we can afford cooling in the summer.

I like turning the tap and getting potable water.

I like having air that is breathable and rivers that don't catch fire.

I like roads that don't swallow my car in potholes and bridges that don't collapse.

Yeah, government sucks. We should get it out of our lives.
What enemy has Little Ricky Sweatervest ever confronted?
Do you know what a college graduate calls "American Exceptionalism"?  "Jingoistic ethnocentrism."   --BG

Now Little Ricky is talking about the VA and saying we don't need it as it exists today, and he is asserting that the 37th best healthcare system as "the best in the world."  

Is he clueless, or is he lying?   --BG

How can Huckabee oppose healthcare for all, and use a root canal as the ruination of a family economically? 

I told you he made my head hurt.   --BG

Bored. Now.

None of these chumps are going to get the nomination. I will return after these guys are done and the really scary guys come out.   --BG

You know what I would like to see? A Democratic commercial that shows a family gathered around a new baby, just home from the hospital, and the doorbell rings...there stands an IRS man with a bill for over thirty grand, and he would congratulate the parents then put the bill in the basinet with the baby and say "Here is the bill for your birth tax." Because that middle-class kid (if the parents are lucky enough to remain middle class) will be paying off the Bush Tax Cuts all his or her working life.   --BG

Governor Huckabee wants a "fair tax" and Jindal wants everyone to have skin in the game. Poor people have a lot more skin in the game than rich people do, percentagewise.

Huckabee is just making my head hurt.   --BG

Told you he was funny...Little Ricky wants a 20% flat tax.

Chris, you dimbulb you, state and local taxes keep going up because of federal tax cuts for the rich (i.e. The Bush Tax Cuts).    --BG
Umm...Chris...you can't opt out of the Federal Exchange, you refused to set up a state exchange, forcing New Jersey residents onto the FEDERAL exchange. You just lied.   --BG

Oh, Chris. You poor victim, you. 

Do you think your threats to the Chinese mean anything, and will he be ab oard Air Force One when it flies over those islands?   --BG
Wow. So Huckabee doesn't believe in facts, reality, or Christian Charity. Good to know.   --BG
Oh, Little Ricky...You're funny, but you ain't Lucy & Desi funny.   --BG

status_message:
So "White Moms Matter"? Is that the takeaway here? Yes. Yes it is. 

I remember being appalled at the passage in "Gone With the Wind" where Scarlett O'Hara scoffs at the notion that the black woman who wet-nurses her children couldn't possibly have the same capacity to love her children as deeply as she herself loved her kids.  Yet in all the years I worked emergency medicine, it was the black mothers who wailed the loudest and fell apart on the spot when they lost a child, not the white ones. Yes it's anecdotal, but it's over 20 years of anecdotal. --BG
link_name: When White People Take Drugs, It Stops Being a "War"

status_message:
Let me tell you about a discussion that was had between an attorney and his assistant when "Citizens United" was before the court. He was fretting and fuming while she was absorbed in a client's medical records. "I dunno..." she said looking up, "It sounds too clever by half to me. Do you really think John Roberts wants his legacy to be the dissolution of the Republican Party? I read the case on Westlaw, too, and I think it will do more damage to the right than the left if this thing becomes the law of the land, at least ultimately. Maybe not in the short-run, but ultimately."

She was right.  --BG
link_name: The Real Effect of Citizens United on the GOP

status_message:
The pundit class is a mendacious lot, and anything that will keep them honest is a good thing, so do it...bring back the snap-polls. 

An interesting aside about snap polls that yours truly was tangentially involved in. During the campaign for Senate in Missouri in 2006, a rumor started floating around that Jim Talent wasn't attending Senate Armed Services Committee meetings. It remained a rumor until one blogger waded through all the transcripts of every SASC meeting since Talent had been on it and discovered he was either absent or asleep and not participating 67% of the time, and we were in two shooting wars. That blogger -- okay, it was me -- called his office and followed up by email, asking if the tale of the transcripts was true, and got totally blown off, not even a "no comment." So what is a blogger with that sort of information to do? Contact the McCaskill campaign (that was somewhat in disarray after a key staffer died in a plane crash during the campaign) and give them the information. Claire hit him with it in a debate, he looked like a deer in the headlights, McCaskill pulled ahead in the overnights, and he never caught up. His base of support -- rural conservatives -- sends more kids off to the military than the average, and those folks didn't appreciate him abdicating his responsibility to their sons and daughters who were fighting two shooting wars at the time. Without the snap-polls that verified that Talent had lost the faith of the electorate, pundits and incumbency would have helped him prevail.  --BG
link_name: Debates Need Snap Polls to Hold Pundits Accountable

Last winter there was a freeway shooter taking shots at cars as the went through the "Grandview Triangle" in southeast Kansas City with a high-powered rifle. status_message:
Here goes the fourth wall again...thirty-four months ago, I had a major neurological event occur, one that claims the lives of more people than survive it. I had a vertebral aneurysm rupture, and during the surgery to repair it, I suffered a stroke and had to learn to walk and swallow all over again. That medical event put me in the bottom quartile of our economy, even though I had spent -- literally -- thirty years doing everything right. (The aneurysm ruptured on Oct. 4, 2012, two days after our 30th anniversary and one day after the first Obama-Romney debate. I literally blamed Obama for the worst headache of my life because he did such a lousy job in that debate.) Now I'm where I never thought I would be and where I worked my tail off **not** to be. Given my new status as po' folk, I appreciate any leveling of the field that can be achieved.

--BG
link_name: Our Democracy is Only Rigged if We Let it Be

status_message:
Has anyone else noticed the difference? Democrats and liberals, ever since FDR, have spoken to our aspirations and calmed our fears. "We have nothing to fear but fear itself," carried a generation through the Depression and World War II. Now comes today's GOP...their motto may as well be "We have nothing but fear itself. And it's twin cousin hatred, of course."

Fortunately, President Obama nor anyone in the Democratic field is jumping on the panic bandwagon, instead they are addressing aspirations instead of fears, and after 14 years of being told to go shopping and seal our windows with plastic sheeting and duct tape and other fear-mongering by the right-wing, Obama's message of hope and change isn't stale. Quite the contrary, it's fresh as a daisy by comparison.

--BG
link_name: Speaking to Our Aspirations Rather Than Our Fears

-- BG
link_name: Remembering New Orleans Before and After Katrina

status_message:
Today marks ten years in what has become, undoubtedly, our nation's greatest domestic failure. 

If I may break the fourth wall again, I have something to contribute. I recall first being shocked, then outraged, when I first heard the term "refugees" applied to American citizens. Then, about two weeks later, I started to see some of them...the free clinic where I volunteered a shift or two a week used the same protocols to process them as we used to process refugees from Somalia, The Sudan or Bosnia. Then, about five months later, at my real job in a suburban hospital where half the business was delivering babies, I started seeing a lot of familiar names in the Blood Bank that ended with "eaux."  Invariably, when I went upstairs to congratulate them on the birth of a healthy baby, they remembered me not as the person who had stuck them with a needle when they first arrived in Kansas City, but as one of the first friendly white faces they had seen in weeks. 

I usually had a good cry in the elevator back to the lab when I had one of those encounters, because I knew Kanye West was right, and it wasn't just George Bush who didn't care. My patient load was empirical, not anecdotal.  #Katrina10  

-- BG

status_message:
Yes, #BlackLivesMatter, but the leaders of the movement are not helping their cause when they attack Bernie Sanders and drive him from the stage at a scheduled, managed event. 

I get it -- they can't get close to Hillary, she has Secret Service protection, and all GOP events are so tightly controlled (John McCain's Missouri chair told one of the Show Me Progress bloggers she would 'cut his heart out' if he posted anything negative, and the way she said it, he believed her) they can't get anywhere near one of those candidates. 

Martin O'Malley is who's grill they should be all up in, but he's schlepping from Pizza Ranch to Pizza Ranch, and finding more people there just to eat and trying to avoid making eye contact than supporters when he gets there, so what would be the point? Their frustrations are boiling over, and they are now at risk of their actions becoming counterproductive, and I, for one, don't want to see that happen.   --BG

status_message:
Just in case anyone isn't familiar with the "Law of Unintended Consequences" we will revisit it's definition before moving on...The Law of Unintened Consequences states that any change to a complex system will have unforeseen or unanticipated consequences. Let's take the Citizen's United ruling...Democrats despaired and Republicans rejoiced, because the intention of Citizens United was to cripple the Democratic Party by defanging their number-one base of support: unions. Instead, something else happened...Every crazy billionaire who thinks his money ought to give him more say over the way things are run has his own Republican candidate to push his agenda, and he can spend as much money as he wants doing so.

Meanwhile, not much changed on the Democratic side. 

Unintended consequences. Gotta love 'em.    --BG

Now the Bastard Sons of Johnny Cash are playing huge festivals of American roots music in France.  --BG

status_message:
Maybe with the white-supremacist terrorist attack in Charleston we're at the tipping point where racism and racial ugliness is concerned. Remember a few years ago when Don Imus got in trouble for a disparaging remark he made about the Rutgers women's basketball team. He didn't understand, black women were referred to the way he had referred to them, and worse, all the time. "Not THOSE women," he was quickly set straight.

Now that six years of untrammeled racial hatred has resulted in the terrorist-style execution of nine pillars of the community for no reason other than they're black, will the right wing noise machine dial it back a notch or two? Please?
link_name: "Until Justice Rolls Down Like Waters"

status_message:
Think of this as earworm transfer: This has been stuck in my head since I saw my 11-year-old in her alb to serve her first Mass this morning. We talk a lot more about community and social responsibility and justice than we do the supernatural aspects of Catholicism...like how the Catholic church was the only organization that stood up to the right-wing death squads and fascist regimes in Central America in the late 70s and 80s. Bertrand Russell was wrong about one thing: The Priest doesn't always side with the dictator, not if he's preaching Liberation Theology -- which is still an unspeakable phrase. Archbishop Romero was assassinated on the altar as he said mass and he was a Jesuit. He was beatified a few weeks ago, and in none of the articles about his beatification, either in English or Spanish, was it acknowledged that he preached Liberation Theology.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lu3VTngm1F0

status_message: I am on the other side of fifty, and it is slowly dawning on me just how lucky I was to spend my youth growing up on desegregated military bases. The segregation I grew up with wasn't racial, it was by rank. Officers lived in nicer houses than the enlisted personnel; but every faith held services at the chapel and in the cases where there wasn't a base school or a Catholic school right outside the gate, the public schools we occasionally attended didn't teach racist history or "scientific racism" because the largest employer in the area wouldn't stand for it since President Truman had desegregated the military in 1948, nearly fifteen years before I was born.  --BG the Brat
link_name: Careful the Tale You Tell…Children Will Listen

status_message:
If a person causes an accident, and a person dies, they are charged with that death, because that death was the impact of the action. But the Chief Justice doesn't think people killed, sometimes murdered in cold blood, by police are entitled to justice based on the outcome of that action. Instead, he thinks it's a fair bar for prosecutors to clear to prove what was in the policeman's mind when he pulled the trigger.

Every day we get closer and closer to losing all confidence in the courts, then Katy bar the door.
link_name: Chief Justice Roberts Wants to Take Another Giant Step Back on Racial Justice

status_message:
Nothing  -- and I do mean it when I say nothing -- makes my blood boil like the false equivalency narrative that "both sides do it."

No, they don't, and I'm sick-to-death of liars pretending otherwise.
Both sides haven't shown their willingness to risk the full faith and credit of the United States by defaulting on the debt ceiling.
Both sides haven't shown a predilliction for wars of aggression.
Both sides haven't declared war on women.
Both sides haven't tried to disenfranchise as many of the other sides voters as possible before the next election.
Both sides DON'T do it, and the next person to say they do ought to be blinded with a hot spoon like that kid in Slumdog Millionaire. Maybe one or two examples like that and people will stop saying dumb things like "both sides do it."

When I worked for the Handy-winning Grand Emporium, I promoted a James Brown show. He was one of the few people I worked with who I was a little starstruck by, and when he arrived he looked at me and said "You Roger Naber's girl?" I felt like my voice was small and squeaky when I said "Yes Sir, Mr. Brown." He stopped dead in his tracks, looked me up and down and said "Don't call me 'Sir,' because I ain't your daddy and you don't owe me money. Now c'mon. Let's get busy and give the folks the show they paid for, to make up for what your boss is underpayin' me."   --BG

status_message: I happily pay every penny and ask the tax guy to make sure I'm paying enough. I like the things we buy with taxes, like roads and bridges and universities and most of all, I like the health care. See, I get my healthcare because my husbands first career was in the Air Force. So when I went face-down on the bathroom tile with a ruptured vertebral aneurysm, we weren't bankrupted by the three weeks of intensive care and three cerebral brain angiograms that followed. I am alive and intact and resumed teaching at a Catholic K-8 this semester because of the the care I got when I needed it.
link_name: Where Every Day Is Tax Day

When I was deciding on a college and a career, she said "Why don't you do something else for a while and wait and see what's next for journalism." I took her advice, went into medicine. This job came along just as I was starting to suffer from burnout.

status_message: When I was a wee lass I was a Navy Brat, and when my Dad got orders that took us to Charleston, SC my parents sat my seven-year-old butt down and had the talk with me...we were about to move to a part of the country where the populace *had* lost a war, and it would be a cold day in hell before they got over it. By the time they were done, I knew what they meant, and I was never so glad to move away from a place in my life, before or since...and I've been sent to Arizona, Wichita, and the Philippines. It goes without saying that I have not returned to The Town That Takes Itself Way Too Seriously.
link_name: Getting in Touch With Your Inner Scalawag

status_message: "The Washington Monthly is looking for thoughtful, creative, driven interns for the spring and for the summer. We have a small staff that produces big stories, so expect to work closely with editors on our website and bimonthly print magazine. We are a nonprofit, independent voice with 45 years of experience understanding Washington and telling fascinating, deeply reported stories about the ideas and characters that animate America's government. This is not a place where interns fetch coffee and observe journalism from the sidelines; you'll be expected to research and fact check stories, manage our (presently being overhauled) social media accounts, and potentially write for the site. This is a part-time paid position, and we can do our best to accommodate a second job if necessary. Please send a resume and any pertinent clips to washingtonmonthlyjobs@yahoo."

status_message: Does anyone else think it's at least possible that the point has been missed entirely...that the only way a Senator has a prayer of getting elected it is after a *short* time in office, not a *long* time; that a thin record is, as they say in Silicone Valley, a feature and not a bug, because every vote cast in the chamber irked someone out there in the general public? Governors can get elected because as a general rule, they have only ticked off half of one state with their actions, but Senators have a federal record that, once examined, ticks off half the COUNTRY.  These three -- Rubio, Cruz and Paul -- have managed to tick off and get mocked by over half the country, but not legislatively.

If I didn't post this as the daylight video, I would be required by my personal moral code to return my Liberal Arts degree and render an apology to the professor who, by the time I got to him had already founded a global hunger relief non-profit. Over 40 years Bill Russell sent a lot of young people out into the world with fully developed critical thinking skills, and no white kid ever left his "Racism & Discrimination" class a bigot. I was there to see him fight for this day, and as far as I'm concerned this is the day to say "Thanks, Bill, for helping me put the pieces together to become the proud liberal who stands before you," because without white guys like Bill Russell fighting for it, Dr. King would not have the official honor he has today. Thanks, Bill.   --BG

status_message:
Say goodbye as the last brick in the fourth wall storms off in a huff...
This is a fabulous idea, and I've been excited about it for twenty years, since Bill Clinton first proposed it. Did I forget to mention that I am a former Community College instructor? From my point of view, kids get to us from disparate backgrounds and they have different skill levels. Not everyone comes out of high school ready to take college Algebra with 249 other students in a letcure hall from a professor who considers questions an annoyance, whereas I cared just as much for the students I taught there as the ones I serve now in a Catholic K-8.
Last night, I had a (mercifully short) Twitter-spat (@BGinKC) with a woman who declared she didn't like it because she "didn't want to pay for it." I finally told her she was already paying for it, via SNAP and subsidized childcare and rental assistance, it's just that the real beneficiaries of those dollars are the employers who can get away with paying slave-wages as long as those programs exist...except I said it in 140 characters...and instead of answering or debating me, she blocked me. So I won.
link_name: Obama's "Free Community College" Initiative

status_message: "Electability concerns" my Aunt Fanny. Fundraising concerns for the state party is more like it. The chairs of the county committees in Iowa are not dispassionate observers who only want what is good for the country. If they want to hold on to their coveted sinecures (which aren't worth much more than bragging rights, but have you ever been to rural Iowa? Bragging rights go a long way...) they willl fill the party coffers, and that is hard to do if there isn't a contested primary.
link_name: The Wing Ding Factor and the Year of "Keeping Hillary Honest"

I want to say a heartfelt thank you to all the readers of this page who clicked over to make  donation -- I'm pretty sure the appeals on Social Media had something to do with the fact that the number of donors was up 23% from our last fundraiser, and the total raised as up 18% -- I'm going to give you guys some of the credit for that. Thank you, thank you, thank you, a thousand times, thank you. Because of your generosity, we'll be here, doing what we do, for another year.

Tammy/Blue Girl

status_message:
Mario Cuomo, from whom I learned you don't run from the word "liberal" when it's hurled at your feet like a grenade, has died. He was 82.  From him I learned to pick that word up, dust it off, put it in my pocket, look the person whe hurled it in the eye and say "Yeah...So?"

 All my politically-aware life he was there, and now he isn't and I'm incredibly sad about that.
link_name: Mario Cuomo Dies at 82, Democrats Soul Searching

status_message:
If I wasn't already a Catholic, I would convert. I love this guy. 

When I was a teenager, the policies of the United States devastated Central America and soaked it in blood. There was exactly one organization that stood up to the right-wing death squads and militias...The Catholic Church, and many brave Sisters and Fathers were martyred at the hands of the death squads that terrorized the countryside. 

He carries the spirits of those brave Sisters and Brothers who preached Liberation Theology  with him. That is why he's important.
link_name: Why Pope Francis Matters to Non-Catholics
